column2: THE MIND HAS AN INCOMPLETE LIFE

column2: The problem of the union of the mind and the body is not one of those which present themselves in pure speculation; it has its roots in experimental facts, and is forced upon us by the necessity of explaining observations such as those we are about to quote.
column3: The problem of the union of the mind and the body is not one of those which present themselves in pure speculation; it has its roots in experimental facts, and is forced upon us by the necessity of explaining observations such as those we are about to quote.

column2: The force of our consciousness, the correctness of our judgments, our tempers and our characters, the state of health of our minds, and also their troubles, their weaknesses, and even their existence, are all in a state of strict dependence on the condition of our bodies, more precisely with that of our nervous systems, or, more precisely still, with the state of those three pounds of proteid substance which each of us has at the back of his forehead, and which are called our brains.
column3: The force of our consciousness, the correctness of our judgments, our tempers and our characters, the state of health of our minds, and also their troubles, their weaknesses, and even their existence, are all in a state of strict dependence on the condition of our bodies, more precisely with that of our nervous systems, or, more precisely still, with the state of those three pounds of proteid substance which each of us has at the back of his forehead, and which are called our brains.

column2: This is daily demonstrated by thousands upon thousands of observations.
column3: This is daily demonstrated by thousands upon thousands of observations.

column2: The question is to know how this union of the body with the consciousness is to be explained, it being assumed that the two terms of this union present a great difference in their nature.
column3: The question is to know how this union of the body with the consciousness is to be explained, it being assumed that the two terms of this union present a great difference in their nature.

column2: The easier it seems to demonstrate that this union exists, the more difficult it appears to explain how it is realised; and the proof of this difficulty is the number of divergent interpretations given to it. column2: Many problems here present themselves.
column3: Many problems here present themselves.

column2: The first is that of the genesis or origin of the consciousness.
column3: The first is that of the genesis or origin of the consciousness.

column2: It has to be explained how a psychical phenomenon can appear in the midst of material ones.
column3: It has to be explained how a psychical phenomenon can appear in the midst of material ones.

column2: In general, one begins by supposing that the material phenomena are produced first; they consist, for instance, in the working of the nervous centres.
column3: In general, one begins by supposing that the material phenomena are produced first; they consist, for instance, in the working of the nervous centres.

column3: Then at a given moment, after this mechanical process, a quite different phenomenon emerges.

column2: Then comes the question whether this production of thought in the midst of physical phenomena is capable of explanation, and how thought is connected with its physical antecedents.
column3: Then comes the question whether this production of thought in the midst of physical phenomena is capable of explanation, and how thought is connected with its physical antecedents.

column2: This principle bears the name of the _axiom of heterogeneity_, or the principle of _psycho-physical dualism_.

column2: Every physical, chemical, or physiological event, in the last resort, simply consists, according to science, in a more or less rapid displacement of a certain number of material elements, in a change of their mutual distances or of their modes of grouping.

column2: Now, what can there be in common, I ask you, what analogy can you see, between this drawing together or moving apart of material masses in space, and the fact of having a feeling of joy, the recollection of an absent friend, the perception of a gas jet, a desire, or of an act of volition of any kind?" And further on: "All that we can say to connect two events so absolutely dissimilar is, that they take place _at the same time_.... This does not mean that we wish to reduce them to unity, or to join them together by the link of causality ... it is impossible to conceive any real connection, any internal relation between these two unconnected things."
column3: Now, what can there be in common, I ask you, what analogy can you see, between this drawing together or moving apart of material masses in space, and the fact of having a feeling of joy, the recollection of an absent friend, the perception of a gas jet, a desire, or of an act of volition of any kind?" This does not mean that we wish to reduce them to unity, or to join them together by the link of causality ... it is impossible to conceive any real connection, any internal relation between these two unconnected things."

column3: It seems to me it should be split up into two propositions of very unequal value: one, the mind and body are heterogeneous; two, by virtue of this heterogeneity it is not possible to understand any direct relation between the two.

column2: I give them, not from the original source, which I am not erudite enough to consult direct, but from the learned treatise which Bain has published on the psychology of Aristotle, as an appendix to his work on the Senses and the Intelligence.

column2: The whole metaphysics of Aristotle is dominated by the distinction between form and matter.
column3: The whole metaphysics of Aristotle is dominated by the distinction between form and matter.

column2: This distinction is borrowed from the most familiar fact in the sensible world--the form of solid objects.
column3: This distinction is borrowed from the most familiar fact in the sensible world-the form of solid objects.

column2: We may name a substance without troubling ourselves as to the form it possesses, and we may name the form without regard to the substance that it clothes.
column3: We may name a substance without troubling ourselves as to the form it possesses, and we may name the form without regard to the substance that it clothes.

column2: But this distinction is a purely abstract one, for there can be no real separation of form from matter, no form without matter, and no matter without form.
column3: But this distinction is a purely abstract one, for there can be no real separation of form from matter, no form without matter, and no matter without form.

column2: The two terms are correlative; each one implies the other, and neither can be realised or actualised without the other.
column3: The two terms are correlative; each one implies the other, and neither can be realised or actualised without the other.

column2: Every individual substance can be considered from a triple point of view: 1st, form; 2nd, matter; and 3rd, the compound or aggregate of form and matter, the inseparable _Ens_, which transports us out of the domain of logic and abstraction into that of reality.
column3: Every individual substance can be considered from a triple point of view: first, form; second, matter; and third, the compound or aggregate of form and matter, the inseparable underscore e n's underscore, which transports us out of the domain of logic and abstraction into that of reality.

column2: Aristotle recognises between these two logical correlatives a difference in rank.
column3: Aristotle recognises between these two logical correlatives a difference in rank.

column2: Form is superior, nobler, the higher in dignity, nearer to the perfect entity; matter is inferior, more modest, more distant from perfection.
column3: Form is superior, nobler, the higher in dignity, nearer to the perfect entity; matter is inferior, more modest, more distant from perfection.

column2: On account of its hierarchical inferiority, matter is often presented as the second, or _correlatum_, and form as the first, or _relatum_.
column3: On account of its hierarchical inferiority, matter is often presented as the second, or underscore correlatum underscore, and form as the first, or underscore relatum underscore.

column2: This difference in rank is so strongly marked, that these two correlations are likewise conceived in a different form--that of the potential and the actual.
column3: This difference in rank is so strongly marked, that these two correlations are likewise conceived in a different form-that of the potential and the actual.

column2: Matter is the potential, imperfect, roughly outlined element which is not yet actual, and may perhaps never become so.
column3: Matter is the potential, imperfect, roughly outlined element which is not yet actual, and may perhaps never become so.

column2: Form is the actual, the energy, the entelechy which actualises the potential and determines the final compound.
column3: Form is the actual, the energy, the entelechy which actualises the potential and determines the final compound.

column2: These few definitions will make clear the singularly ingenious idea of Aristotle on the nature of the body, the soul, and of their union.
column3: These few definitions will make clear the singularly ingenious idea of Aristotle on the nature of the body, the soul, and of their union.

column2: The body is matter which is only intelligible as the _correlatum_ of form; it can neither exist by itself nor be known by itself--that is to say, when considered outside this relation.
column3: The body is matter which is only intelligible as the underscore correlatum underscore of form; it can neither exist by itself nor be known by itself-that is to say, when considered outside this relation.

column2: The soul is form, the actual. By uniting with the body it constitutes the living subject.
column3: The soul is form, the actual. By uniting with the body it constitutes the living subject.

column2: The soul is the _relatum_, and is unintelligible and void of sense without its _correlatum_.
column3: The soul is the underscore relatum underscore, and is unintelligible and void of sense without its underscore correlatum underscore.

column2: The soul, says Aristotle, "is not a variety of body, but it could not exist without a body: the soul is not a body, but something which belongs or is relative to a body." The animated subject is a form plunged and engaged in matter, and all its actions and passions are so likewise.
column3: The soul, says Aristotle, "is not a variety of body, but it could not exist without a body: the soul is not a body, but something which belongs or is relative to a body." The animated subject is a form plunged and engaged in matter, and all its actions and passions are so likewise.

column2: Each has its formal side which concerns the soul, and its material side which concerns the body.

column2: The emotion which belongs to the animated subject or aggregate of soul and body is a complex fact having two aspects logically distinguishable from each other, each of which is correlative to the other and implies it.
column3: The emotion which belongs to the animated subject or aggregate of soul and body is a complex fact having two aspects logically distinguishable from each other, each of which is correlative to the other and implies it.

column2: Intelligence, like emotion, is a phenomenon not simply of the corporeal organism nor of the [Greek: Nous] only, but of the commonalty or association of which they are members, and when the intelligence weakens it is not because the [Greek: Nous] is altered, but because the association is destroyed by the ruin of the corporeal organism.
